applicability.conditions: Mobile sampling along streets in Xuzhou City, China (warm temperate semihumid monsoon climate). Meteorological variables (air temperature and absolute humidity) and street-view images were collected synchronously at pedestrian height around midday in late summer (September 2, 2020) with a 20 s sampling interval. Street images were segmented using SegNet to compute Green View Index (GVI) and Construction View Index (CVI) representing proportions of visible greenery and built/hard-paved elements in the human visual field along streets.

source.citation: Zhou, H., Tao, G., Yan, X., & Sun, J. (2021). Influences of greening and structures on urban thermal environments: A case study in Xuzhou City, China. Urban Forestry & Urban Greening, 66, 127386.

applicability.conditions: Street-side greenery (Green View Index) measured from Baidu Street View panoramic images captured in four directions at sampling points across the street network in Shangcheng District, Hangzhou, China. GVI computed via HSV color thresholding (60–180 degrees as green) and averaged across four directional images per point; accuracy checked using 100 manually interpreted images. Analysis relates GVI to surrounding environmental characteristics (e.g., road hierarchy, land use, water areas, residential parcels, facade/wall design).

source.citation: Zhu, J., Qiu, L., Su, Y., Guo, Q., Hu, T., Bao, H., Luo, J., Wu, S., Xu, Q., Wang, Z., & Pan, Y. (2022). Disentangling the effects of the surrounding environment on street-side greenery: Evidence from Hangzhou. Ecological Indicators, 143, 109153.

They are complementary axes and should not be treated as redundant; do not infer LCZ from space type unless the source explicitly states it or the inference basis is documented in applicability.conditions.

applicability.conditions: Street-level urban greenery assessment using Green View Index (GVI) derived from standardized street view images (SVIs) from online mapping platforms. Study area is Hangzhou, China, focusing on 593 well-built roads (about 1,658.61 km) in and near the central district (8 districts), excluding tunnels and roads under construction or in peri-urban areas. GVI computed via semantic segmentation (Deeplab-V3+) with vegetation classes (tree, shrub, herb) and compared across road patterns (number of greenery belts/bars) and vegetation structures (e.g., tree-herb, tree-shrub, tree-shrub-herb).

source.citation: Zhu, H., Nan, X., Yang, F., & Bao, Z. (2023). Utilizing the green view index to improve the urban street greenery index system: A statistical study using road patterns and vegetation structures as entry points. Landscape and Urban Planning, 237, 104780.

applicability.conditions: Urban residents' walking exercise preferences analyzed using street view images and smartphone app trajectory data in Changsha, China. Streetscape visual indicators (openness, greenness, enclosure, facilities, blueness, walkability, beauty) derived via semantic segmentation (DeepLabv3) and scenic beauty estimation; preferences compared by time of day, gender, and age groups (primarily 20–40).

source.citation: Zhu, J., Li, B., Ouyang, H., Wang, Y., & Bai, Z. (2024). Understanding Urban Residents' Walking Exercise Preferences: An Empirical Study Using Street View Images and Trajectory Data. Buildings, 14(2), 549.

applicability.conditions: Urban forest park trail-walking context. Case study in the North Park section of Gongqing Forest Park (Shanghai), a large forest landscape area with clear main/secondary roads suitable for walking tours. Walking preference/intensity derived from crowdsourced GPS tracking and kernel density estimation, combined with on-site observations, panoramic street-level imagery, and UAV orthophotos; correlations and OLS used to relate top-view and eye-level scene characteristics to walking preferences. Data collected on non-rainy days from June 10–15 and July 3–10, 2024, between 08:00 and 18:00.

source.citation: Zou, J., Jiang, H., Ying, W., & Qiu, B. (2024). Scenic Influences on Walking Preferences in Urban Forest Parks from Top-View and Eye-Level Perspectives. Forests, 15(11), 2020.
